question: Price tends towards the level which equates supply with demand'. Explain this statement.
answer:
(i) Price of goods is determined by the interaction of the forces of demand and supply.

(ii) If the price is at a level where supply is less than demand, then there will be excess demand which may increase the price. For example, at price OP\(_1\), OQ\(_2\) was supplied while OQ\(_3\) was demanded.

(iii) If the price is at a level where supply is greater than demand (above equilibrium), there would be excess supply, leading to a fall in price. For example, at price OP\(_2\), OQ\(_4\) was supplied while OQ\(_1\)  was demanded.

(iv) The equilibrium price is OP\(_0\) where demand is equal to supply. There is no tendency for price to change. The quantity supplied is equal to quantity demanded at OQ\(_0\)

question: Highlight the economic problems associated with the dependency of West African countries on primary production.
answer:
The economic problems associated with the dependency of West African countries on primary production are:
(i) The development of substitutes
(ii) The type of weather in West Africa makes it difficult for them to shift the focus of their production.
(iii) West African nations may be forced to depend solely on imported capital and semi-finished goods.
(iv) Diversification of the economy. becomes difficult because of competition from foreign countries
(v) Another basic problem is the difficulty of developing new markets.
(vi) The reliance on primary production can cause overproduction hence a fall in price. The revenue will reduce gradually.
(vii) The terms of trade will deteriorate drastically.
(viii) Vulnerability to world recession and price fluctuations

question:
(a) Explain the term national debt.
(b) State any four instruments of government borrowing in Nigeria.
answer:
(a) National or public debt is the debt a country owes to its citizens or other countries or organisations such as International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. The debt which a country owes its citizens is known as internal debt, while the debt owed foreign governments and organisations is known as external debt.

(b) Instruments of government borrowing in Nigeria are:

(i) Treasury certificate: These are securities for medium term borrowing. They are for a period of one to two years and they carry higher rate of interest than treasury bills.

(ii) Treasury bills: These are securities used for short-term borrowing for about 90 days. This carries low rate of interest.

(iii) Development stock: These are referred to as government stock and they are used for long-term borrowing of up to five years and above.

(iv) Negotiations: The government can borrow from external financial institutions

(v) National savings scheme.

question: Compare and contrast the private limited company with the public limited company.
answer:

(i) Both have legal status.

(iii) There is continuity of existence.
(iv) There is large capital outlay.
(v) Powers are exercised through memorandum and Article of Association
(vi) Both companies may be voluntarily or compulsorily liquidated.

question:
(a) Outline the main features of the Malthusian theory on population.
(b) Explain the developments that render the theory irrelevant to the present day situation.
answer:
(a)The main features of the Malthusian theory are:
(i) That population was growing at a geometrical progression while food production was growing at arithmetical progression.

(ii) That there is a tendency for all living things to grow beyond the food available to them.

(iii) Unless population increase is matched with means of subsistence, negative and positive checks will come into force.

(iv) That population is essentially limited by the means of subsistence.

(b) The theory has become irrelevant due to the following facts:
(i) The development in technical knowledge and mechanization of agriculture to increase food supply.
(ii) Changes in social attitudes as regards family size.
(iii) Increased efficiency in the transportation system enables more materials to be provided to areas that needed them.
(iv) The industrial revolution also changed the idea of land as a fixed factor of production.
(v) Opening of new colonies which provided the needed land
(vi) The interdependency of nations as a result of international trade.

question: What is money ? Explain its characteristics.
answer:
Money is anything that is generally acceptable as a medium of exchange ( for instance, as a means of settling debts) and at the same time acts as a measure and a store of value. e.g naira and kobo in Nigeria.

The characteristics of Money are:

(i) Divisibility : It should be divisible into convenient units without losing its value, e.g. N50, N20 etc.

(ii) General acceptability: It should be acceptable in the society in which it is used.

(iii) Relatively scarce: It must be relatively scarce but not too scarce.

(iv) Portability: It should be easy to carry about.

(v) Durability : It should be able to last for a long period of time.

(vi) Homogeneity: The money material must be the same size and quality. Twenty naira note held by Mr. B must be the same twenty naira held by Mr. A in any part of the country.

(vii) Stability: The value of money must be stable.

question:
(a) Explain the term capital market.
(b) How is the capital market different from the stock exchange?
(c) What are the advantages of the capital market?
answer:
(a)The Capital Market is the market for medium term or long term loan. The Capital Market serves the needs of industry and the commercial sector. The Capital Market is made up of the following institutions: Issuing houses, insurance companies, development banks etc. It comprises all the institutions which are concerned with either the supply of or demand for long term capital.

(b) How Capital market is different from the stock exchange as it is a market for long term loan while the stock exchange market is a specialized market for the buying and selling of securities, i.e, claims to loans or shares.

(c) Advantages of the capital market are:
(i) Provision of long term loan to the private and public sector for investments
(ii) Savings are mobilized in the capital market.
(iii) It encourages the growth of merchant banks.
(iv) The general public can also participate in the running of the economy of a country.

question: Describe the functions of the International Monetary Fund (IMF).
answer:
The following are the functions of IMF:
(i) To promote international monetary cooperation.
(ii) To promote stability in exchange arrangements among members and to avoid competitive exchange rate or depreciation
(iii)To provide financial aid to member nations experiencing balance of payments difficulties on a temporary basis
(iv) It gives financial aid to members having balance of payments difficulties.
(v) The I.M.F. establishes and maintains stable exchange rates between member countries.
(vii) To help developing nations pay their trading partners in foreign currency.
